tool.name: miniasm
tool.description: Ultrafast de novo assembly for long noisy reads

param.label: Drop mappings having less than this number of matching bases
During read filtering, ignore mappings with col10/col11 below this value
param.help: Ignored mappings are still used for read overlaps

param.label: Drop mappings shorter than this number bp
param.help: This option also affects the second round of read filtering and minimal overlap length

param.label: Minimal coverage by other reads
param.help: In the first round of filtering, miniasm finds the longest region covered by this number or more reads. In the second round, it in addition requires each remaining base to be covered by INT bases at least minSpan/2 from the ends of other reads

param.label: Maximum overhang length
param.help: An overhang is an unmapped region that should be mapped given a true overlap or true containment. If the overhang is too long, the mapping is considered an internal match and will be ignored

param.label: Minimal ratio of mapping length to mapping+overhang length for a mapping considered a containment or an overlap
param.help: This option has a similar role to MaxHang, except that it controls the ratio, not length

param.label: Maximal gap differences between two reads in a mapping
param.help: This parameter is only used for transitive reduction

param.label: Maximal probing distance for bubble popping
param.help: Bubbles longer than this value will not be popped

param.label: A unitig is considered small if it is composed of less than this many reads
param.help: Miniasm may try to remove small unitigs at various steps

param.label: Overlap drop ratio threshold after short unitig removal

tool.help: Miniasm is a very fast OLC-based de novo assembler for noisy long reads. It takes all-vs-all read self-mappings (typically by minimap) as input and outputs an assembly graph in the GFA format. Different from mainstream assemblers, miniasm does not have a consensus step. It simply concatenates pieces of read sequences to generate the final unitig sequences. Thus the per-base error rate is similar to the raw input reads.
